description: Explore atomic structure, chemical bonding, states of matter, and reaction kinetics through the lens of physics

slides.title: Welcome to Physical Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Physical Chemistry âš›ï¸

Welcome to **Physical Chemistry** - where chemistry meets physics!

## What you'll learn:
- **Atomic Structure** - Electrons, orbitals, and quantum numbers
- **Chemical Bonding** - How atoms stick together
- **States of Matter** - Gases, liquids, and phase changes
- **Reaction Rates** - How fast reactions happen
- **Chemical Equilibrium** - Balance in reactions

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Physical chemistry explains WHY chemistry works using principles from physics!

## Why Study Physical Chemistry?
- ðŸ”¬ **Understand reactions** - Predict behavior at molecular level
- âš¡ **Energy** - Batteries, fuel cells, solar cells
- ðŸ’Š **Drug design** - Molecular interactions
- ðŸŒ¡ï¸ **Materials** - Polymers, semiconductors, nanomaterials

## The Physical Chemistry Approach

| Traditional Chemistry | Physical Chemistry |
|----------------------|-------------------|
| What happens? | Why does it happen? |
| Descriptive | Quantitative |
| Recipes | Predictions |
| Phenomena | Mathematical models |

Let's explore the physics behind chemistry!

slides.title: Atomic Structure
slides.content:
# Atomic Structure ðŸ”µ

## The Atom

```
                      Electron cloud
                    â—     â—     â—
                  â—               â—
                â—    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â—
               â—     â”‚Nucleusâ”‚     â—
                â—    â”‚ p+ n  â”‚    â—
                  â—  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜  â—
                    â—    â—    â—
```

## Subatomic Particles

| Particle | Symbol | Charge | Mass (u) | Location |
|----------|--------|--------|----------|----------|
| Proton | pâº | +1 | 1.007 | Nucleus |
| Neutron | n | 0 | 1.009 | Nucleus |
| Electron | eâ» | -1 | 0.00055 | Orbitals |

## Atomic Number & Mass Number

```
    Mass number (A) = protons + neutrons
    á´¬
    â‚‚X   Example: Â¹Â²â‚†C
        
    Atomic number (Z) = protons
```

## Isotopes

Same element, different number of neutrons:

| Isotope | Protons | Neutrons | Mass Number |
|---------|---------|----------|-------------|
| Â¹H (hydrogen) | 1 | 0 | 1 |
| Â²H (deuterium) | 1 | 1 | 2 |
| Â³H (tritium) | 1 | 2 | 3 |

## Atomic Mass

Weighted average of all isotopes based on natural abundance.

Example: Chlorine has 75% Â³âµCl and 25% Â³â·Cl
Atomic mass = 0.75(35) + 0.25(37) = **35.5 u**

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** The nucleus contains 99.9% of the atom's mass but only 0.00001% of its volume!

slides.title: Electron Configuration
slides.content:
# Electron Configuration ðŸ“Š

## Quantum Numbers

Each electron is described by four quantum numbers:

| Number | Symbol | Values | Describes |
|--------|--------|--------|----------|
| Principal | n | 1, 2, 3... | Energy level/shell |
| Angular momentum | l | 0 to n-1 | Subshell shape |
| Magnetic | ml | -l to +l | Orbital orientation |
| Spin | ms | +Â½ or -Â½ | Electron spin |

## Subshell Shapes

| l | Subshell | Shape | Max electrons |
|---|----------|-------|---------------|
| 0 | s | Sphere | 2 |
| 1 | p | Dumbbell | 6 |
| 2 | d | Cloverleaf | 10 |
| 3 | f | Complex | 14 |

## Filling Order (Aufbau Principle)

```
1s â†’ 2s â†’ 2p â†’ 3s â†’ 3p â†’ 4s â†’ 3d â†’ 4p â†’ 5s â†’ 4d â†’ 5p â†’ 6s...
```

## Rules for Electron Configuration

### 1. Aufbau Principle
Electrons fill lowest energy orbitals first.

### 2. Pauli Exclusion Principle
No two electrons can have the same four quantum numbers.

### 3. Hund's Rule
Electrons occupy empty orbitals before pairing.

## Example: Iron (Fe, Z=26)

```
1sÂ² 2sÂ² 2pâ¶ 3sÂ² 3pâ¶ 4sÂ² 3dâ¶

Or: [Ar] 4sÂ² 3dâ¶
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Shortcut:** Use noble gas notation for simpler writing!

slides.title: Atomic Structure Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of atomic structure!
slides.quizQuestion: How many electrons can the 3d subshell hold?

slides.title: Ionic Bonding
slides.content:
# Ionic Bonding ðŸ”‹

## What is Ionic Bonding?

Electrostatic attraction between **positive** and **negative ions** formed by electron transfer.

## How Ionic Bonds Form

```
    Na (11 eâ»)  +  Cl (17 eâ»)
         â†“              â†“
    Naâº (10 eâ») + Clâ» (18 eâ»)
         â†“              â†“
    Noble gas      Noble gas
    config (Ne)    config (Ar)
```

## Electron Transfer

| Metal atoms | Non-metal atoms |
|-------------|----------------|
| Lose electrons | Gain electrons |
| Form cations (+) | Form anions (-) |
| Left side of table | Right side of table |

## Properties of Ionic Compounds

| Property | Explanation |
|----------|-------------|
| High melting point | Strong electrostatic forces |
| Hard and brittle | Rigid crystal lattice |
| Conduct electricity (molten/dissolved) | Free ions move |
| Soluble in water | Water molecules separate ions |

## Crystal Lattice Structure

```
    + - + - +
    - + - + -
    + - + - +
       NaCl lattice
```

Each Naâº surrounded by 6 Clâ» and vice versa!

## Lattice Energy

Energy released when gaseous ions form solid crystal.

**Higher lattice energy = Stronger ionic compound**

Factors: Smaller ions & higher charges â†’ Higher lattice energy

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Ionic bonds form between metals and non-metals!

slides.title: Covalent Bonding
slides.content:
# Covalent Bonding ðŸ¤

## What is Covalent Bonding?

Atoms **share electrons** to achieve stable electron configurations.

## How Covalent Bonds Form

```
    HÂ· + Â·H â†’ H:H (or H-H)
    
    Each H now has 2 electrons (like He)
```

## Types of Covalent Bonds

| Bond Type | Electrons Shared | Example |
|-----------|------------------|--------|
| Single | 2 | H-H |
| Double | 4 | O=O |
| Triple | 6 | Nâ‰¡N |

## Bond Strength and Length

| Bond | Strength | Length |
|------|----------|--------|
| Single | Weakest | Longest |
| Double | Medium | Medium |
| Triple | Strongest | Shortest |

## Polar vs Non-Polar Covalent

### Non-polar
- Equal sharing of electrons
- Same or similar electronegativity
- Examples: Hâ‚‚, Oâ‚‚, CHâ‚„

### Polar
- Unequal sharing of electrons
- Different electronegativity
- Examples: Hâ‚‚O, HCl, NHâ‚ƒ

```
         Î´-
          O
         / \
      Î´+ H   H Î´+
      
    (Water is polar!)
```

## Properties of Covalent Compounds

| Property | Explanation |
|----------|-------------|
| Low melting/boiling point | Weak intermolecular forces |
| Poor conductors | No free ions |
| Often gases/liquids | Weak forces between molecules |
| Insoluble in water (usually) | Non-polar |

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Covalent bonds form between non-metals!

slides.title: Metallic Bonding
slides.content:
# Metallic Bonding ðŸ”©

## What is Metallic Bonding?

Metal cations in a "sea" of delocalized electrons.

```
    + eâ» + eâ» + eâ» +
    eâ» + eâ» + eâ» + eâ»
    + eâ» + eâ» + eâ» +
    eâ» + eâ» + eâ» + eâ»
    
    Metal cations (+) in electron sea (eâ»)
```

## How Metallic Bonds Form

1. Metal atoms release valence electrons
2. Electrons become delocalized
3. Positive ions held together by electron sea

## Properties Explained

| Property | Explanation |
|----------|-------------|
| **Electrical conductivity** | Electrons move freely |
| **Thermal conductivity** | Electrons transfer energy |
| **Malleability** | Layers can slide |
| **Ductility** | Can be drawn into wires |
| **Lustrous** | Electrons reflect light |
| **High melting point** | Strong attraction |

## Why Metals are Malleable

```
    + + +         + + +
    + + +   â†’     + + +
    + + +           + + +
    
    Layers slide without breaking bonds!
```

## Comparing Bond Types

| Property | Ionic | Covalent | Metallic |
|----------|-------|----------|----------|
| Particles | Ions | Molecules | Cations + eâ» |
| Bonding | Electrostatic | Shared electrons | Electron sea |
| Melting point | High | Low | Variable |
| Conductivity | Molten/solution | No | Yes |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** The "sea of electrons" explains all metallic properties!

slides.title: Bonding Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of chemical bonds!
slides.quizQuestion: Which type of bond involves the transfer of electrons?

slides.title: States of Matter
slides.content:
# States of Matter ðŸ§ŠðŸ’§ðŸ’¨

## The Three Main States

| State | Particle Arrangement | Properties |
|-------|---------------------|------------|
| **Solid** | Fixed, close together | Fixed shape & volume |
| **Liquid** | Close but can move | Fixed volume, takes container shape |
| **Gas** | Far apart, random motion | Fills container |

## Kinetic Molecular Theory

1. Matter is made of particles in constant motion
2. Temperature = average kinetic energy
3. Higher temperature = faster particles

## Phase Changes

```
                    Sublimation
            â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
            â”‚                        â”‚
            â†“                        â†‘
    SOLID â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’ LIQUID â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’ GAS
          Melting    Vaporization
          Freezing   Condensation
            â†‘                        â†“
            â”‚                        â”‚
            â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                    Deposition
```

## Energy During Phase Changes

| Term | Definition | Formula |
|------|------------|--------|
| Heat of fusion (Hf) | Energy to melt | Q = m Ã— Hf |
| Heat of vaporization (Hv) | Energy to boil | Q = m Ã— Hv |

## Heating Curve

```
Temp â”‚               ______ Boiling
     â”‚              /
     â”‚     ________/
     â”‚    /
     â”‚___/ Melting
     â”‚
     â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’ Heat added
```

**Flat sections:** Phase change (temperature constant)
**Sloped sections:** Warming within a phase

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Insight:** During phase changes, energy changes the arrangement of particles, not their temperature!

slides.title: Gas Laws
slides.content:
# Gas Laws â›½

## Ideal Gas Behavior

Assumptions:
- Particles have no volume
- No intermolecular forces
- Elastic collisions

## The Gas Laws

### Boyle's Law (T constant)
```
Pâ‚Vâ‚ = Pâ‚‚Vâ‚‚
```
Pressure and volume are inversely proportional.

### Charles's Law (P constant)
```
Vâ‚/Tâ‚ = Vâ‚‚/Tâ‚‚
```
Volume and temperature are directly proportional.

### Gay-Lussac's Law (V constant)
```
Pâ‚/Tâ‚ = Pâ‚‚/Tâ‚‚
```
Pressure and temperature are directly proportional.

### Combined Gas Law
```
(Pâ‚Vâ‚)/Tâ‚ = (Pâ‚‚Vâ‚‚)/Tâ‚‚
```

## Ideal Gas Law

```
PV = nRT
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| P | Pressure | Pa or atm |
| V | Volume | L or mÂ³ |
| n | Moles | mol |
| R | Gas constant | 8.314 J/(molÂ·K) |
| T | Temperature | K (Kelvin!) |

## Standard Conditions

| Condition | STP | SATP |
|-----------|-----|------|
| Temperature | 273.15 K | 298.15 K |
| Pressure | 1 atm | 1 bar |
| Molar volume | 22.4 L/mol | 24.8 L/mol |

## Example

**How many moles in 5 L of gas at STP?**

n = PV/RT = (101325)(0.005)/(8.314)(273) = **0.22 mol**

> ðŸŽ¯ **Always use Kelvin for temperature in gas laws!

slides.title: Reaction Rates
slides.content:
# Reaction Rates & Kinetics â±ï¸

## What is Reaction Rate?

The speed at which reactants are consumed or products are formed.

```
Rate = -Î”[Reactant]/Î”t = +Î”[Product]/Î”t
```

## Factors Affecting Rate

| Factor | Effect | Why? |
|--------|--------|------|
| **Concentration** | â†‘ Rate | More collisions |
| **Temperature** | â†‘ Rate | Faster particles |
| **Surface area** | â†‘ Rate | More contact |
| **Catalyst** | â†‘ Rate | Lower activation energy |
| **Pressure (gases)** | â†‘ Rate | More collisions |

## Collision Theory

For reaction to occur:
1. Particles must **collide**
2. With enough **energy** (â‰¥ activation energy)
3. In the correct **orientation**

## Activation Energy (Ea)

```
Energy â”‚    Ea
       â”‚   /\  â† Transition state
       â”‚  /  \
       â”‚ /    \____
       â”‚/     Products
       â”‚Reactants
       â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’ Reaction progress
```

## Rate Laws

```
Rate = k[A]^m[B]^n
```

| Symbol | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| k | Rate constant |
| [A], [B] | Concentrations |
| m, n | Reaction orders |

## Arrhenius Equation

```
k = Ae^(-Ea/RT)
```

Higher T or lower Ea â†’ Larger k â†’ Faster reaction

> ðŸ’¡ **10Â°C Rule:** Roughly, reaction rate doubles for every 10Â°C increase!

slides.title: Chemical Equilibrium
slides.content:
# Chemical Equilibrium âš–ï¸

## What is Equilibrium?

When forward and reverse reactions occur at **equal rates**.

```
aA + bB â‡Œ cC + dD

At equilibrium:
Rate(forward) = Rate(reverse)
```

## Dynamic Equilibrium

- Reactions don't stop!
- Continuously converting both directions
- Concentrations remain constant

## Equilibrium Constant (K)

```
K = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b
```

| K value | Meaning |
|---------|--------|
| K >> 1 | Products favored |
| K << 1 | Reactants favored |
| K â‰ˆ 1 | Neither favored |

## Le Chatelier's Principle

> *When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to counteract the change.*

| Change | System Response |
|--------|----------------|
| â†‘ Reactant concentration | Shifts right (â†’) |
| â†‘ Product concentration | Shifts left (â†) |
| â†‘ Temperature (exothermic) | Shifts left (â†) |
| â†‘ Temperature (endothermic) | Shifts right (â†’) |
| â†‘ Pressure | Shifts to fewer gas moles |

## Example

**Nâ‚‚ + 3Hâ‚‚ â‡Œ 2NHâ‚ƒ + heat**

- Add Nâ‚‚ â†’ Shifts right, more NHâ‚ƒ
- Add heat â†’ Shifts left, less NHâ‚ƒ
- Increase pressure â†’ Shifts right (4 mol â†’ 2 mol)

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Equilibrium is dynamic - reactions continue but cancel out!

slides.title: Kinetics Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of reaction rates!
slides.quizQuestion: A catalyst increases reaction rate by:

slides.title: Thermochemistry Basics
slides.content:
# Thermochemistry ðŸ”¥

## Energy in Chemical Reactions

### Enthalpy (H)
Heat content of a system at constant pressure.

```
Î”H = H_products - H_reactants
```

## Exothermic vs Endothermic

| Type | Î”H | Energy | Example |
|------|----|---------|---------|
| Exothermic | Negative | Released to surroundings | Combustion |
| Endothermic | Positive | Absorbed from surroundings | Photosynthesis |

## Energy Diagrams

**Exothermic:**
```
Energy â”‚ Reactants
       â”‚    \___
       â”‚        \___ Products
       â”‚         Î”H < 0
       â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’
```

**Endothermic:**
```
Energy â”‚         Products
       â”‚    ___/
       â”‚___/      Î”H > 0
       â”‚ Reactants
       â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’
```

## Hess's Law

> *The enthalpy change of a reaction is independent of the pathway.*

We can add up Î”H values for multiple steps!

## Standard Enthalpy Changes

| Type | Symbol | Meaning |
|------|--------|--------|
| Formation | Î”HfÂ° | Form 1 mol from elements |
| Combustion | Î”HcÂ° | Complete burning |
| Neutralization | Î”HnÂ° | Acid + base â†’ salt + water |

## Calculating Î”H

```
Î”HÂ°reaction = Î£Î”HfÂ°(products) - Î£Î”HfÂ°(reactants)
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Insight:** Energy is always conserved - if a reaction releases energy, surrounding temperature increases!

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Congratulations! ðŸŽ‰

You've completed Physical Chemistry! Here's what you've mastered:

## Atomic Structure
- âœ… Protons, neutrons, electrons
- âœ… Quantum numbers (n, l, ml, ms)
- âœ… Electron configuration rules

## Chemical Bonding
- âœ… **Ionic:** Electron transfer, metal + non-metal
- âœ… **Covalent:** Electron sharing, non-metals
- âœ… **Metallic:** Electron sea, metals

## States of Matter
- âœ… Solid, liquid, gas properties
- âœ… Phase changes and energy
- âœ… Kinetic molecular theory

## Gas Laws
- âœ… Boyle's, Charles's, Gay-Lussac's
- âœ… **Ideal Gas Law: PV = nRT**

## Reaction Rates
- âœ… Collision theory
- âœ… Factors affecting rate
- âœ… Activation energy and catalysts

## Equilibrium
- âœ… Dynamic equilibrium
- âœ… Equilibrium constant K
- âœ… Le Chatelier's principle

## Thermochemistry
- âœ… Enthalpy (Î”H)
- âœ… Exothermic vs endothermic
- âœ… Hess's Law

> ðŸš€ **Next Steps:** Explore Inorganic Chemistry to dive into the periodic table and its trends!

You now understand the physical principles underlying chemical behavior!
